RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Sabrina Marczak é Doutora em Ciência da Computação pela University of Victoria, Victoria, Canadá (2011), Mestre (2003) e Bacharel (2001) em Ciência da Computação pela Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio Grande do Sul (PUCRS). Atualmente, é professora adjunta da Escola Politécnica da PUCRS na área de Engenharia de Software e Sistemas de Informação, e pesquisadora do grupo de pesquisa MunDDoS. Colaboradora do grupo de pesquisa CRADL, da University of California, Irvine, US e parceira internacional do SINTEF, The Foundation for Scientific and Industrial Research, Trondheim, Norway. Seus interesses de pesquisa na área de Engenharia de Software têm ênfase em desenvolvimento de software colaborativo e engenharia de requisitos, em particular em cenários de desenvolvimento distribuído de software. Mais especificamente, as subareas de interesse são: (1) colaboração e maturidade em desenvolvimento ágil em larga escala, (2) aspectos humanos no desenvolvimento de software, (3) gamification para apoio à colaboração, (4) qualidade de requisitos com o uso de práticas ágeis, (5) melhoria de processos de software e (6) engenharia de software empírica. Sabrina é coordenadora do Convênio de pesquisa e desenvolvimento Dell/PUCRS, no qual coordena (entre outros) o projeto de pesquisa que investiga a adoção de métodos ágeis em larga escala utilizando tecnologias específicas. Atuou como Assessora de Pesquisa na Agência de Gestão Tecnológica da PUCRS, negociando projetos de pesquisa junto a empresas candidatas à parceria com a PUCRS. Também atuou como gerente do projeto CMMI-3, em parceria com a Microsoft e ISD Brasil, e como analista de qualidade no Centro de Desenvolvimento de Software da Dell Brasil.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Sabrina Marczak is an Adjunct Professor in the School of Technology at the PUCRS University, Brazil, where she acts as a researcher collaborator of the Munddos Research Group. She holds a PhD degree in Computer Science from the University of Victoria, Canada. Her research areas are collaborative software engineering and requirements engineering in particular in geographically distributed software development projects. More specifically her areas of interest include (1) large-scale agile development, (2) soft aspects of global software development such as communication and trust, (3) gamification as a collaboration motivator, (4) requirements quality, (5) software process improvement, and (6) empirical software engineering. She is currently the coordinator of the Dell/PUCRS Research Agreement where she leads the large-scale agile development project, among other responsibilities. She has worked at the Research Technology Agency of the PUCRS Technology Park (Tecnopuc) negotiating research projects with prospective IT companies. She has also managed the CMMI-3 project in partnership with Microsoft and ISD Brazil, and worked as a Software Quality Assurance Analyst at Dell Brazil.

OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES: Sabrina Marczak é colaboradora e parceira de pesquisa em diversos projetos e universidades ao redor do mundo incluindo Twente University, The Netherlands (Prof Maya Daneva); University of Gothenburg, Sweden (Prof Eric Knauss); Open University (Prof Helen Sharp); e Universidade Federal do Pará (Prof Cleidson de Souza); Universidade Federal do Amazonas (Profa. Tayana Conte); Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Norte (Prof. Fernando Figueira Filho); e Universidade Federal do Paraná (Profa. Rafaela Fontana).

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES: Bolsista do Projeto OOLDER - Object-Orientation Learning, Development and Reuse, o qual tinha por objetivo desenvolver um ambiente para formalizar o aprendizado de Orientação a Objetos. Pesquisa financiada pelo CNPq.
Estágio realizado no Laboratório de Línguas Estrangeiras do Instituto de Artes e Letras da PUCRS, auxiliand professores e alunos no uso de tecnologias de informação.

Monitor de disciplinas dos cursos de Graduação de Ciência da Computação e Análises de Sistemasa. A carga horária indicada é uma média entre as horas dedicadas para as três disciplinas de monitoria realizadas.

Estagiária bolsista de Pós-Graduação do Centro de Desenvolvimento e Pesquis em E-Business (CDPE), o qual é parte do Convênio Dell/PUCRS. Este Centro tem como objetivo treinar estagiários de Graduação e Pós-Graduação nas tecnologias adotadas pela Dell Inc., através da participação dos mesmos nos projetos de desenvolvimento de software do Brazil Global Development Center (Brazil GDC). Também tem como objetivo realizar pesquisas para atender as necessidades do Brazil GDC. Estas pesquisas estão organizadas por Centros de Competências (CoC).

Ministrando disciplinas em cursos oferecidos pela Faculdade de Informática, como Engenharia de Software e Sistemas de Informação, e coordenadora de projeto (Projeto CMMI3, convênio Microsoft/PUCRS, em parceria com ISD Brasil)
Professora Horista da Faculdade de Informática, na área de Engenharia de Software. Também atuando como orientadora de Trabalhos de Conclusão de Curso de Graduação (Sistemas de Informação).
Colaboradora da equipe de Negociação de Projetos de P&DI com candidatos a parceiros da PUCRS. Também responsável pelo programa de melhoria de processos internos da AGT.
VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-INGLES: A posição de Assistente de Pesquisa da Agência de Gestão Tecnológica da PUCRS tem como objetivo assessorar na negociação e definição de projetos de P&DI da PUCRS com empresas privadas e governamentais.

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES: Professora Adjunta da Escola Politécnica (ex-Faculdade de Informática - até Dez/2017), na área de Engenharia de Software. Também atuando junto ao Programa de Pós-Graduação em Ciência da Computação, como orientadora e avaliadora de Trabalhos de Conclusão de Cursos de Graduação (Sistemas de Informação e Ciência da Computação) e coordenadora de projetos.

A Comissão Científica tem como principais responsabilidades: (a) propor diretivas para a elaboração de projetos de pesquisa e desenvolvimento com parceiros acadêmicos e da indústria e (b) apoiar à Direção da Faculdade de Informática em assuntos relacionados à questões científicas como um todo.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The main goal of this research project was to further the understanding about requirements-driven collaboration. To achieve this goal, we (1) empirically examine processes of communication and knowledge management in the coordination necessary to the development of software requirements in order to further the understanding of requirements-driven collaboration, and (2) developed a framework that defines an approach to examine requirements-driven collaboration and that offers a set of techniques that allows one to perform this examination.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: The Effects of Distance, Experience, and Communication Structure on Requirements Awareness in Two Distributed Industrial Software Projects

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Global Requirements Engineering Workshop (GREW 07)
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Global Requirements Engineering Workshop (GREW'07) in conjunction with the International Conference on Global Software Engineering (ICGSE 07)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In global software development, communication is difficult due to distance between sites. How effectively do team members distributed among multiple geographical locations become aware of changes and clarifications to requirements? In a case study of two different global software development projects, we observed how requirement analysts, developers, and testers maintain awareness of changes in the project. To gather data, we attended local and remote meetings, and conducted interviews of project team members. Based on our experience with these projects, we discuss the following awareness factors in software development: distance, experience of team members, and communication structure. We present the effects on awareness, and provide some lessons learned for global software development projects. We expect these lessons learned can be used by projects with similar settings.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Social Networks in the Study of Collaboration in Global Software Teams

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: International Conference on Global Software Engineering (ICGSE 07)
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Global Software Engineering (ICGSE 07)

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Collaboration Patterns and the Impact of Distance on Awareness in Requirements-Centred Social Networks

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: International Requirements Engineering Conference (RE 07)
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Proceedings of the 15th International Requirements Engineering Conference (RE 07)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Because of intense collaborative needs, requirements engineering is a challenge in global software development. How do distributed teams manage the development of requirements in environments that require significant cross-site collaboration and coordination? In this paper, we report research that used social network analysis to explore collaboration and awareness among team members during requirements management in an industrial distributed software team. Using the lens of a requirements-centred social network to group team members who work on a particular requirement, we collected data to characterize requirements-centric collaborations in a project, and to examine aspects of awareness of requirements changes within these networks. Our findings indicate organic patterns of collaboration involving considerable cross-site interaction, in which communication of changes was the most predominant reason for interaction. Although we did not find evidence that distance affects developers' awareness of remote team members who work on the same requirements, distance affected how accessible the remote colleagues were. We discuss implications for knowledge sharing and coordination of work on a requirement in distributed teams, and propose directions for the design of collaboration tools that support awareness in distributed requirements management.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Patterns of Information Flow in Interdependent Requirements Social Networks and Implications for Requirements-Driven Collaboration

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Socio-Technical Congruence Workshop (STC 08)
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Socio-Technical Congruence workshop (STC 08), in conjunction with the IEEE International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE 08)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Requirements interdependencies create technical dependencies among project members that generally belong to different functional groups in an organization, but who need to coordinate activities due to changes in requirements or related artifacts. In our work we study aspects of requirements-driven collaboration and which we relate to processes of communication and coordination in cross-functional teams whose members work on same or interrelated requirements. We study coordination that considers technical dependencies as created by requirements interdependencies, and not just those derived from code artifacts. In this paper we describe our approach and report from a field study of requirements interdependencies, the associated technical dependencies and patterns of information brokerage in the social networks generated by the work on the interdependent requirements.
Little is known about processes of information flow and brokerage in social networks built around interdependent requirements. In a field study at a large IT manufacturing organization we found that brokers holding pockets of knowledge have an impact on information flow in requirement-interdependent teams. We discuss a number of patterns of information flow and draw implications for processes of requirements change management.

Marczak, S.; Damian, D.; Stege, U.; Schroter, A.; Dept. of Comput. Sci., Univ. of Victoria, Victoria, BC
This paper appears in: International Requirements Engineering, 2008. RE '08. 16th IEEE Issue Date: 8-12 Sept. 2008 On page(s): 53 - 62 Location: Catalunya ISSN: 1090-705X Print ISBN: 978-0-7695-3309-4 INSPEC Accession Number: 10397279 Digital Object Identifier: 10.1109/RE.2008.26 Date of Current Version: 21 November 2008 Abstract
Requirements interdependencies create technical dependencies among project members that generally belong to different functional groups in an organization, but who need to coordinate activities during processes of requirements change management. Effective knowledge management is needed to disseminate information on requirement changes across teams working on interdependent requirements to avoid mis-interpretations. Social networks are regarded as important in fostering knowledge management, where brokers or gatekeepers have the role of project members facilitating information flow. However, little is known about processes of information flow and brokerage in social networks built around interdependent requirements. In a field study of requirement interdependencies in a large IT manufacturing organization, we found that brokers holding pockets of knowledge have an impact on information flow in requirement-interdependent teams. We discuss a number of patterns of information flow and draw implications for processes of requirements change management.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Investigating Collaboration Driven by Requirements in Cross-Functional Teams

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Collaboration and Intercultural Issues on Requirements Communication, Understanding and Softskills Workshop (CIRCUS 09)
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Proceedings of the Collaboration and Intercultural Issues on Requirements Communication, Understanding, and Softskills Workshop, in conjunction with the IEEE International Requirements Engineering Conference

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Achieving effective collaboration is an ongoing challenge in software development, and requirements engineering inherits this challenge. By taking a requirements perspective on collaboration we can better understand how cross-functional teams coordinate work throughout the project life-cycle. In this paper we report on a case study of a global IT company that investigated requirements-driven collaboration in a cross-functional team. We studied collaboration by examining the congruence between the technical dimension of work and social relationships team members establish. We calculated the mismatch between the social and technical dimensions. Based on the results, we critically analyzed the applicability of congruence to the study of cross-functional software teams as well as the limitations of current socio-technical congruence measures, which have been applied to only study developer teams. Based on this work, methods to investigate congruence between the social and technical dimensions of work have to be extended to incorporate information about pre-deﬁned structures in the organization.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Using a Real-Time Conferencing Tool in Distributed Collaboration: An Experience Report from Siemens IT Solutions and Services

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: IEEE International Conference on Global Software Engineering (ICGSE 09)
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Global Software Development

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Successful distributed collaboration requires support for informal communication, opportunistic interactions, and smooth and frequent shifts between synchronous and asynchronous collaboration modes. Introducing new collaboration tools for distributed interaction is often regarded as a difficult organizational endeavor, compounded by a lack of concrete, empirical evidence of expected improvements in tool-supported distributed collaboration. In this paper, we describe the introduction of the Microsoft Office Communication Server collaboration tool to improve collaboration in a distributed project at Siemens IT Solutions and Services. Improvements included (1) faster response and resolution time on issues that involve cross-site communication; (2) enhanced productivity of global teams, enhanced sense of teamwork, and motivation in the global team; and (3) flatter communication structures across sites. We discuss lessons learned from the adoption of the collaboration tool and factors that made it possible.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Towards a Theory of Knowledge Management Processes Underlying Requirements-Driven Collaboration

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: How Interaction between Roles Shapes the Communication Structure in Requirements-Driven Collaboration

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: IEEE International Requirements Engineering Conference
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Proceedings of the IEEE International Requirements Engineering Conference

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Requirements engineering involves collaboration among many project team members. Driven by coordination needs, this collaboration relies on communication and knowledge that members have of their colleagues and related activities. Ineffective coordination with those who work on require- ments dependencies may result in project failure. In this paper, we report on a study of roles and communication structures in the collaboration driven by interdependent requirements in a software team. Through on-site observations, interviews with the developers and application of social network analysis, we found that there was significant communication between diverse roles in the project, and identified what were the reasons for communication between the different roles. We also found that these interactions typically involved a core of requirements analysts and testers in close communication, that most often they involved critical members whose absence, whether temporary or permanent, would disrupt the information flow if removed from the project, as well as that new hires were mostly isolated from the team collaboration. Most interestingly we found that the emergent communication structure between the different roles in the project did not conform to the planned communication structure prescribed by the organization. These findings further our knowledge about collaboration driven by requirements, and provide some useful implications for research and development of collaborative tools to support the effective coordination of cross-functional teams in software development.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-CAPITULO.TITULO-DO-CAPITULO-DO-LIVRO: Requirements-Driven Collaboration: Leveraging the Invisible Relationships between Requirements and People

DETALHAMENTO-DO-CAPITULO.ORGANIZADORES: Ivan Mistrik; John Grundy; Andre van der Hoek; Jim Whitehead

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In this chapter we introduce requirements-driven collaboration, which is the collaboration of a cross-functional team of business analysts, designers, developers and testers during the development and management of requirements. We describe an approach that (1) constructs a requirement-centric social network which represents the membership and relationships among members working on a requirement and its associated downstream artifacts and (2) outlines a number of social network analysis techniques to study collaboration aspects such as communication, awareness, and the alignment of technical dependencies driven by development of requirements and social interactions. To demonstrate our approach, we discuss a case study that examines requirements-driven collaboration within an industrial, globally-distributed software team. Finally, we discuss implications regarding the use of our requirements-driven collaboration approach for research and practice.

A vida acadêmica não está completa para aqueles que querem se tornar pesquisadores ou professores quando a graduação termina. Doutorado é requisito obrigatório, seja por lei ou para adquirir experiência na carreira que se inicia. Bons cursos de doutorados estão disponíveis no Brasil e incentivos não faltam para que alunos permaneçam no país. Mas estudar no exterior ainda é uma opção considerada por muitos. Quais razões levam um brasileiro a cursar doutorado pleno (curso completo) ou sanduíche (aluno visitante) no exterior? Quais são as possíveis opções em termos de bolsas de estudo? Qual o vínculo com a universidade de origem e a no exterior? Como é a vida acadêmica daqueles que estudam fora? E a vida social do estudante? Baseado em nossas experiências buscamos, neste artigo, responder a estas questões. Também destacamos as semelhanças e as diferenças de cursar doutorado pleno ou sanduíche no exterior e apresentamos as lições aprendidas com nossas experiências.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-RELATORIO-DE-PESQUISA.TITULO: Graph Theory Applied to Social Networks on Requirement Engineering: An Investigation Based on an Industry Case Study Conducted in Brazil

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Requirements engineering is an important discipline in Software Development. It requires significant collaboration and coordination among project team members in order to gather, define, document, and manage the requirements. Keeping team members aware of up-to-date information about requirements and their evolution in a dynamic environment is a challenge, especially for distributed teams. In a past industry case study of a distributed software project, Damian, Marczak and Kwan find that awareness and communication about requirements are correlated. Now, one wants to investigate if this correlation also exists when people are working on inter-related requirements. Social Network approaches have been used to identify patterns of communication, collaboration and coordination in organizations by analyzing social relationships among collaborators. Comparing the actual networks to the formally defined one is a powerful method to reveal hidden issues in organizations.
